DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for E. Curll in Fleetstreet. M.DCC.XIX.

DIV2.HEAD: COLLISHULL, alias Coleshall,
DIV2.P: Against the South Wall of the Chancel is a very stately, arched Monument, erected for Sir Henry Pratt, and his La∣dy, whereon lye both their Representa∣tions cut in White Marble; he being clad in Armour, over which is a loose Mantle lined with Fur; she habited and fashion∣ed in the Dress of the Times wherein she lived. Within the Arch, on a large Black Marble, is this Inscription.

Q.P:
This Monument conceales the Ashes of the late honourable, prudent, and pious, Sir HENRY PRATT, Knight and Ba∣ronett, who by God's Providence, ac∣quired the Eminence of Sheriff, and Alderman of London, and the honour∣able Dignity of Knight and Baronet.
The Memoriall of the Just shall be pre∣served, but the Name of the Wicked shall rot, Prov. 10. ver. 7. He lived 75 Yeares, and deceased the vi Day of Aprill, MDCXLVII.
Phoenix moriendo reviviscit.

DIV2.HEAD: ASHBURY,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Deanery of Abing∣ton. Patron the Right Honourable the Lord Craven, Incumbent Mr. White.
In the middle of the Chancel lyes a Grave-stone, bearing on it a Plate of Brass, whereon is the Figure of a Man in the Habit of a Batchelor of Law, and be∣neath his Feet is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Magister Willielmus Skel∣ton, utriusque Iuris Baccalau∣rius quondam prepositus in Ec∣clesia Cathedrali Wellenci & Rec∣tor istius Ecclesie acetiam Rector Ecclesie Sancti Vedasti in Civitate London, qui obiit XXVIII. Die Mensis Marcii. Anno Domini, MCCCCXLVIII. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: At his Feet is another Grave-stone, and thereon a Plate also, containing these Verses.

Q.L: Continet hec fossa de Walden ossa Johannis,
Quem Deus ad celsa ducat perpetuus annis.

DIV2.P: On another Plate of Brass fastened to a Grave-stone laid near unto the North Wall, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Hic facet Dominus Thomas de Bushbury, Canonicus dum vtxit in Ecclesia HertfordPatius Hereford., & Rector istius Ecclesie; qui obiit XXIX Die Menfis Marcii, Anno Domini, MCCCCIX.
Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.

DIV2.P: In the middle of this Grave-stone is the Figure of the said Bushbury vested in his Habit.
On a flat Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth Jane, the Wife of Alexander Popham, Es{que} who departed this Life, May the xxixth, Anno Domini, MDCXCVII.
DIV2.P: On a Grave-stone in the North Isle is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet corpus Ricardi Harding, Generosi, qui ob. xxix Die Maii, An∣noque Domini, MDCLXXVIII. Aetatis suae 76.
DIV2.P: At Ashbury Park, in this Parish, is a Camp of an oblong Figure, about an 100 Paces Diameter, and the Works single, which is an Evidence of its Danish Origi∣nal. It is now almost destroyed, by dig∣ging for the Sarseden Stones, to build a House for the Right Honourable Pro∣prietor the Lord Craven.

DIV2.HEAD: COMPTON-BEAUCHAMP.
DIV2.P: Upon a Brass Plate set in a Blue Grave-stone, laid in the middle of the Chancel, is the following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Magister Willielmus Frampton, Rector istius Ecclesie. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: Upon a Monument fixed in the South Wall is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here under lieth interred the Infant Body of Christian White, Grief of his Parents that he died, their Joy that he died a Christian, May xxi, MDCXVIII.
Rest Babe in Christ, the God who gave thee Breath,
Rewards with lasting Life thy speedy Death;
Thy Life was like thy length, all but a Span,
See here, proud Flesh, how vain a Thing is Man!
DIV2.P: On another small Stone fixed in the North Wall is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here lieth the Body of Margaret White, who died the xxth of July, An. Domini, MDCXXVII. in her tender Years. Morier.
A Week of Yeares I lived, and that exprest,
God call'd me hence to Heavens Sabbatick rest;
I run according to my Yeares, my Race,
And God's Glory crownes in me his Grace.
Orier.
DIV2.P: This Rectory is in the Deanery of A∣bington. Lord of the Manor, and Pa∣tron, Edward Richards, Es{que} present In∣cumbent the Reverend Mr. Langley.

DIV2.HEAD: OFFINGTON, alias Uffington, alias Wolston,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Deanery of Abing∣ton. Patron Mr. Archer, Incumbent the Reverend Mr. Pomfret.
Against the North Wall of the North Cross Isle of this Church, is erected a large Monument of Free Stone, in the middle whereof are these Inscriptions in manner following.

Q.P: Here lyeth the Body of EDWARD ARCHER, Es{que} buried the xxviith Day of July, and in the first Yeare of the Raigne of our Soveraigne Lord King James, and in the Yeare of our Lord God, MDCIII.
The Lord it Mercifull and Righteous, and our God is full of Compassion. Precious in the Sight of the Lord is the Death of his Saints, Psalm 116. vers. 5, & 15.
Archer's Arms 3 Arrows.

DIV2.P: In the middle of the North Cross Isle is a raised Monument of Free-Stone, and this Epitaph engraven thereon.

Q.L: In obitum JOHANNIS GROVE de
Balking Generosi, & MARGARETAE Uxoris ejus.
Hoc maerens posuit Auctor Epitaphium.

DIV2.P: On a Grave-stone lying in the middle of the Nave of the Church, on a Brass Plate, is this Epitaph.)
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Bodies of JOHN SAUN∣DERS, and ANNE his Wife, both borne in this Parish; which John had two Wives, the other named. JONE, and had Yssue by his first Wife 5 Sons and 2 Daughters, who departed this Lyfe the xxvi Day of Decemb. Anno Dom. MDXCIX.
DIV2.P: In the West Wall of the South Cross Isle of the Church, is a fair arched Monu∣ment adorned with carved Work, and gilded, whereon lyes the Statue of a Per∣son in a Barrister of Laws Gown, and over him is this Inscription.

Reader, this Monument presents the Memory of JOHN SAUNDERS, of Wol∣ston, in the County of Berks, Esquire, and Justice of the Peace in that Coun∣ty, and well experienced in the Com∣mon Lawes of England. He render∣ed his Soule to God the xxixth Day of Aprill, MDCXXXVIII. And this Portion of Sacred Earth preserves his Body, which is sequestred for the Re∣surrection. He was happy in his Mar∣riage with MARGARET, one of the Daughters of JOHN EVELYN of God-stone, in the County of Surrey, Es{que} at whose Charge this Monument was erected, and by whome he had Chil∣dren ELIZABETH, MARGARET, THO∣MAS, ELIZABETH and LETTICE.

DIV2.HEAD: SPERSHOLT,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Deanery of A∣bington. Patron Queen's College in Ox∣ford, Incumbent the Reverend Mr. Bell.
On a Brass Plate fixed in a Grave-stone, laid near the middle of the Chan∣cel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Hic jacet JOHANNIS FETTIPLACE Generosus, qui Uxorem duxit MARGA∣RETAM ANDREWS Vid. unam filiarum THOMAE BRAYBROOKE de Abingdon Generos. & obiit.... die Februarii, Anno 1602.
Hoc tumulo Fetiplace requiescunt ossa Johannis,
Et parvum corpus parvula terra tegit.
Sed mes quae melior pars est expersque sepulchri,
Infima despiciens, sidera celsa colit.
DIV2.P: On a Grave-stone in the middle of the Chancel is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of JOHN WILLIAMSON, Batchelor of Divinity, Vicar of this Church, deceased October the xxth. 1633.
DIV2.P: Next below, another Grave-stone with this Inscription on Brass.
DIV2.Q: Hic sepultus est NICOLAUS COOKE, Ar∣tium Magister, Socius Collegii Reginae Oxon. hujus Ecclesiae Rector, qui obiit Aug. 1603.

EPIGRAPH.Q: Deus eorum qui obdormierunt in Jesu deducent cum eo.

DIV3.P: Adjoyning to the latter is the Figure of a Priest in his Habit, cut in Brass, set in a small Stone, under which is this In∣scription.
DIV3.Q: Hic jacet Dominus Thomas Mythson quondam Scolaris Collegii Regi∣ne Oxoniae, & istius Ecclesie Vica∣rius. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV3.P: Circumscribed on the Body of a large Stone, whereon is the Figure of an Ec∣clesiastick in his Habit, this Inscription.
DIV3.Q: + Hic jacet Willielmus de Herleston Rector..... hanc cancel∣lam, & Obiit ultimo die Febr.... Domini MCCC.......... Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV3.P: On another Grave-stone laid on the North Side of the Chancel are the two following Inscriptions.

Q.P: Off your Charitie pray for the Soule...sumetyme Vicar of this Church, who...... 30. On whole Soule, and all Christian Soulles...

Hic jacet corpus THOMAE TODHUN∣TER, hujus Ecclesiae quondam Vicarii, & Collegii Reginae olim Socii, qui sibi quinque habebat notos, viz. duos filios & tres filias. Obiit 30 die Martii, & sepultus erat 1•. die Aprilis, Anno Dom. MDCXXVII.

DIV3.P: On another Grave stone is the following Inscription.
DIV3.Q: Hic jacent corpora Petri Hunsdon & Marie Vxoris ejus, que quidem Maria obiit ultimo die Maii, A0. Domini, 1543. & Petrus postea quarum animarum propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV3.P:
In an Arch cut into the South Wall of the Chancel, lyes the Statue of a Knight in Mail, cross legged, having a short Coat girt over his Armour, and holding his Hands in the Posture of praying; be∣tween
his Feet is an Eagle standing up∣right.

In the middle of this Chapel stands an antient raised Monument of Wood, and thereon the Statue of a Knight in plate Armour, with a short Coat over it, cut also in Wood, his Hands, like the for∣mer, are erect, and his Feet rest upon a Lion. Under his Head lyes his Helm, on which, out of a Crown, issues something like a Mushroom.

Under the South Window are two large Arches made in the Wall; in that towards, the West, lyes the Statue of a Woman cut also in Wood, and veiled. In the other, more Eastward, lyes a Man veiled like∣wife, his Feet resting on two little Dogs.
At the Front of this last Monument are the Figures of Nine Men compleatly armed, holding their Swords and Shields in various Postures.
On a Grave-stone in this Chapel is this Inscription.
DIV3.Q: Here lyeth the Body of JONE WAL∣RONE, the Wife of THOMAS WAL∣RONE, who dyed Ao. MDCX.
DIV3.P: At the East End of this Chapel is a Monument with this Inscription.
DIV3.Q: Here lyeth the Body of JOHN PLAY∣DELL, Gent. who was buried Aprill the xviith. An. MDXCI. Also the Body of BRIDGET his Wife, who de∣ceased Febr. xiv. Ao. MDCXXIII. Which John and Bridget had 7 Sons and 6 Daughters, and Three are buri∣ed in this Isle, ANTHONY, SAMUEL, and KATHERINE.
DIV3.P: On another Monument On the same Wall is this Inscription.
DIV3.Q: Here was buried the ixth of Aprill, MDCXXV. the Body of Sir GEORGE HYDE, Knight of the Honourable Or∣der of the Bath to our Soveraigne Lord King James, at his Coronation of Eng∣land; and had to Wife KATHERINE, the Daughter of Sir HUMFRY FER∣RARS, of Tamworth Castle, in the County of Warw. and had by her 3 Children.
DIV3.P: On a Grave-stone lying in the Body of the Church, under the Figures of a Man, and his two Sons and two Daughters, is this Inscription.

Q.L: Pray for the Soule, and pray you dere,
Of, Thomas Bothe that lyeth here.

DIV2.HEAD: CHILDREY,
DIV2.P: Is situate in the Hundred of Wanting, and Deanery of Abington, and was for∣merly the Seat of a Family of the Name of Childrey, one of whom lyes buried in the Church, and is hereafter mentioned, he had 3 Daughters, Co-heiresses, among whom this Manor was divided. The present Lords and Possessors are Sir Oliver Ayshcombe, Sir Ferdinando Fetiplace, and ... Knight, Es{que} At this Place is founded a Free School by William Feti∣place, Es{que} a singular Benefactor to Queen's College in Oxford.
Not far from this Place runs the famous Roman Way, called Ickenyldstreet, so admi∣rably traced out by the learned Roger Gale, Es{que} to Streatly.

In the middle of the Chancel lyes a very large Marble Stone, adorned with the Pourtraitures of a Man in Armour tread∣ing on a Lion, and his Wife near him, both holding up their Hands in a Devoti∣onal Posture, and this Inscription towards the lower End of the said Grave-stone.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacent Willielmus Ffynderne Armiger & Domina Elizabetha Vx∣or ejus, & quondam Vxor Domini Johannis Kyngeston Militis. Qui quidem Willielmus obiit 13o die Mensis, Marcii Ano. Domini 1444. & dicta Domina Elizabetha obiit... die Menf. ... Ao. Domini, 14... Quorum animabus propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: This following Circumscription is en∣graved likewife in Brass.

Q.L: Armiger eximius fuerat, legisque peritus
Et fidus munus subjacet hic posittus.
Willielmus dictus Ffynderne fuit & veneratus.
Crimine non victus consilioque satus.
Donis gratuitis ipsum natura beabit
Sors sublimavit undique fortuitis
Quam sponsarat heram clatam, doctam, quoque ve∣ram
Kingston Elizabeth hic locus unus habet.
Quos thorus admisit unus, lapis iste relissit
Grandis marmoreus, his miserere Deus.
Ossa tegit plana petra, quoan sit quotidiana
Hic imperpetuum mencio spirituum
Crastina dum preerit lux Gregorii benedicti
Willielmi dicti vita brevis deerat.
Armus millenus quater & C preteriete,
Et quater undenus tunc subiere fere.
Illuc qui propeis pedibus conscendis ad atas,
Funde prcces caros, sint socii supeis.
Si quos leserunt, vel qnod male promeruerunt,
Aosis Christe tamen, pace fruantur. Amen.

DIV2.P: Within an Arch of the North Wall of a Chapel built on the North Side of the Church, lyes a Knight cross legged, arm∣ed in Mail, and a short Coat over it. He bears his Shield on his left Hand, and seems to be drawing his Sword. His Feet rest upon a Lion.
On a Brass Plate set in a Grave-stone (Eastward of that laid for William Ffyndeme) is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic acet Demina Agnes quondam Vxor Johannis Ffynderne, que obiit 5 die Februarii, Ao. Domini, 1441 Cuus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: On a Marble adjoyning, whereon is represented a Doctor of Law in his Har∣bit, in a Brass Plate, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Of your Charitie pray for the Soule of Bryan Roos, Doctor of Law, sumtyme Parson of this Church; the whych deceased the
30th Day of August, the Yer of our Lord God, 1529. On whose Soule Ihesu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: In the North Wall of the Chancel, and near to the East Window, is a fair Arch, wherein a Body hath been antiently laid, and near thereunto is a Marble, where∣upon, in Brass Plates, are the Figures of a Man in Armour, and his Wife in her usual Habit and Attire, under whose Feet is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Of your Charitie pray for the Sowle of John Kingeston, Esquire, Sone and Ayre sumtymes of John Kingestone; the wyche forsayd John departed from this transytory Lyfe, the 16 Day of Apryle in the Yere of owre Lord God, 1514. and for the Sowle of Susan his Wyfe, the wyche departyd thys transy∣tory Lyfe the... in the Yere of our Lord 15... and... On whose Sowlles Ihesu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: On a Scrowl proceeding out of the Man's Mouth.
DIV2.Q: O Ihesu, dulcedo omnium te amancium.
DIV2.P: On a Scrowl coming out of the Wo∣man's Mouth.
DIV2.Q: Et semper adjutor ad te perorantium.
DIV2.P: In a Chapel erected on the South Side of the Church are laid several Grave-stones, whereon are engraved the following E∣pitaphs.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Willielmus Walrond Gen. qui quidem Willielmus obiit... die Mensis... Anno Domini Millimo CCC... que quidem Elizabetha obiit... die Mens.... Anno Dom. Millimo CCCC... Quorum animabus propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: Near the little South Door, on a Grave-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here under that Marble Stone, next before the Ymage of Sent Mighell, resteth the Bodies of Tho∣mas Wallrond, Gentilman, and
Alice his Wife, Daughter of Ni∣cholas Englefield, whiche Alice de∣ceased the... Day of.... the Yere of our Lord 1477. and the said Tho∣mas decessed the 16 Day of Septem∣bre, the Yere of our Lord 1480. On whose Soules Ihesu have Mercy.
DIV2.P: Under the Figures of a Man and Wo∣man, and the Picture of the Holy Trini∣ty above them, is this Inscription.

Q.L: Maker of Mankind. O God in Trinitie,
Of thyn high Mercy grant me this bon,
That for my Sowle, seth a Pater Noster and Ave,
Daughter to Thomas Walrond baptise by the Name of Jone,
Wife, when I in the World lived, to Robert Straughbon,
The Second Day of Aprill hence passed and leyd in her Grave,
Ther alder Sowles, Mercy, Lord, grant them to have. Amen.
Obitus, Ano. Dni. Millimo... Septimo.

DIV2.P: On another Grave-stone is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV2.Q: Here under this lyeth the Bodies of William Feteplace, Esquite, and Elizabeth his Wife, Founder of this Chauntery, founded in the Honour of the blessed Trinity, our Lady, and Sent Kateryn; whiche Elizabeth decessed the 14 Day of Ja∣nuary,
DIV2.P: On a Brass Plate set in a Grave-stone (East ward of that laid for William Ffynderne) is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic iacet Dcmina Agnes quondam Uror Johannis Ffynderne, que obiit 5 die Februarii, Ao. Domini, 1441. Cu us anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: On a Marble adjoyning, whereon is represented a Doctor of Law in his Ha∣bit, in a Brass Plate, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Of your Charitie pray for the Soule of Bryan Roos, Doctor of Law, sumtyme Parson of this Church; the whych deceased the
Of your Charitie pray for the Sowle of John Kingeston, Esquire, Sone and Ayre sumtymes of John Kingesstone; the wyche forsayd John departed from this transytory Lyfe, the 16 Day of Apryle in the Yere of owre Lord God, 1514. and for the Sowle of Susan his Wyfe, the wyche departyd thys transy∣tory Lyfe the... in the Yere of our Lord 15... and... On whose Sowlles Ihesu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: On a Scrowl proceeding out of the Man's Mouth.
DIV2.Q: the Yeare of our Lord 1516. and the said William decessed the .... Day of...... in the Yeare of our Lord God 15.... On whose Sowles, and all Christian Soules, Ihesu have Mercy.
DIV2.P: On another Grave-stone is the following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth buried the Bodies of ELIZA∣BETH and KATHERINE FETIPLACE, Daughters of ALEXANDER FETIPLACE, who departed this Lyfe, Ano. Dom. 1603.
DIV2.P: On a Monument in the Form of an Al∣tar set in the Wall, are the Figures of a Man and Woman in winding Sheets, seeming to rise out of their Graves.

In the East Window of this Chapel are Pictures of a Man in Armour, having on a Surcoat of the Arms of Fetiplace; and of a Woman with a Surcoat on of the Quarterings impaled with Fetiplace, and both kneeling.
In the Hall Windows of the Manor House are painted the under mentioned Coat of Arms.
Something Northward of Pusey, in the Deanery of Abington, lyes the Vicaridge of

DIV2.HEAD: North DENCHESWORTH.
DIV2.P:
This was the antient Inheritance of the Family of the Fetyplaces, one of whom, Sir Philip, was Lord of this Manor, temp. Edw. 1. and bore for his Arms, in a Field, 2 Chevron, quartering also the Coat of the Lord St. Amand, as is evident from a Seal made use of by him, with his Name round it, in the Time of that King. Tho∣mas Fetyplace, of Pusey, Es{que} descended from the said Sir Philip, was not many Years since Lord of this Place. Not far from Wantage lyes South Denchesworth, the antient Inheritance of the Hydes, of which Family Sir Walter de Hyde, Knt. temp. Edw. 1. the last of whom, at this Place, was Sir George Hyde, created Knight of the Bath at the Coronation of King James I. who sold this Manor to Sir Wil∣liam Cockayne, Knt. Alderman of London, whose Son the Viscount Cullen, of Ireland, sold it to the Father of the present Lord of the Manor, Gregory Geering, Es{que} Within the Bounds of this Parish, is an Estate known by the Name of HYDE,
where is yet visible a large Square Moat, judged to have been a Fish-Pond. It is highly probable, that the Family of Hydes took their Name from this Seat; they be∣ing in old Evidences and Writings fre∣quently termed at Hyde. This Family has formerly been very remarkable in this Place, where they have been Lords for Nineteen Generations. The Church is dedicated to St. James the Apostle, and was founded by one of this Family, whose Arms are visible in the Windows, and Walls, both of the Church and Chancel. Over the Porch, at the Request of Mr. Kedden, the present Vicar, the Patron, Mr. Geering, in 1693. erected a small Li∣brary, into which he put several valuable Books for the Use of the Vicars for ever; to which Library also, Mr. Edward Brew∣ster, of London, Stationer, was a generous Benefactor.
This was formerly a small Vicaridge, worth annually about 20 Nobles, but was augmented by the Viscount Cullen, in 1662. to 23 £. 6 s. 8 d. Annum.

In a Chapel situate on the North Side of the Church is a raised Monument, and thereon lye the Figures of a Man in Ar∣mour, and his Wife in the Habit of the
Times wherein she lived, at whose Feet is this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Of your Charitie pray for the Soules of Oliver Hyde, Esquire, and Agnes his Wife: the which Oliver decessed in the Yere of our Lord God 1516.
DIV2.P: On whose Soules Ihesu have Mercy. Amen.
Under the Man are the Figures of four Sons, and under the Woman are four Daughters.
On a Plate of Brass set in a Grave-stone lying in the aforesaid Chapel, is this Inscription.

Q.L: Nudos nos mundo matrix perduxerat alvus,
Et tursum nuda corpora terra petit.
Quas donavit opes munbus sibi vendicat omnes,
Nee poscessorem gasa sicuta suum.
Sed neque divitie generis, nec gloria, quenquam
A mortis poterit tollere lege virum
Say michi nomen erat Willelmus, me nece stratum
Decima quinta dies Aprilis ab orbe vocavit,
Anno Domini Millimo CCCCLXXXXIII.
Queso suum, quicunque meum bustum videt
Cogitet, & dicat, Say requiesce polo.

DIV2.P: Under the Figures of a Man and his Wife, he in Armour, and she in her usual Dress, is the following Inscription cut on Brass, and fixed on a Grave-stone.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth William Hyde, Esquire, whome God took to his Mercy, and was buried the 22th Day of July, in the Yeare of our Lord God, 1567. And also here lyeth Alice, Wife of the said William Hyde, whome God also took to his Mercy. the... Day of... in the Yere of our Lord God 15... Which William, and Alice his said Wife, in their Life-time, had 10 Children of their two Bodies law∣fully begotten; that is to say, 5 Sons and 5 Daughters.
DIV2.P:
On a Plate of Brass fixed in a Grave-stone placed at the Entrance into the said South Chapel, are these Verses.
Here lye we two enclosed now in Erth, not far a part,
Husband and Wife, whiles we had lyfe, whom only Death could parte;
My Name William, her's Margery, by surname called Hyde,
Whych Name accord to us live and dead, whom now the Erthe doth hyde;
Whyle we dyd lyve God gave us Grace, to harbour, clothe, and hyde,
The naked poore Folkes: Injuries we did defend and hyde;
Now being dead, we crave Mercy of God, that he will hyde
Hys Face from our Synnes and with hys Arme he from the Devyll us hyde,
And that with Saints and happy Soulles, our sely Soules may byde,
In Heaven with God, good Folkes we pray, to pray to God for Hyde.
Upon a large Plate of Brass nailed to the South Pillar of the Arch entring into the Chancel, directly over the a∣bove-mentioned Grave-stone, is cut the Figure of the said William Hyde in Ar∣mour, and his Wife, both kneeling at a Desk; behind him are the Figures of eleven Sons, and behind her of Nineteen Daughters, all kneeling.
Out of his Mouth comes this Scrowl.
DIV2.Q: Miserere mei, Deus, secundum mag∣nam misericordiam tuam.
DIV2.P: Out of his Wife's Mouth is this Scrowl.
DIV2.Q: Heale my Soule O Lord, for I have sinned against Thee.
DIV2.P: Under both the Pourtraitures.

Q.P: Quisquis transieris, pro nostls ora animabus, Et junctos tumulo tu prece junge Deo.
The which William Hyde, Esquire, decessyd the Second Day of May, in the Yere of our Lord God 1557. and the said Margerv, hys Wyfe de∣cessyd the 27 Day of June, in the Yere of our Lord God 1562.

DIV2.HEAD: ARDINGTON,
DIV2.P: In the South Isle is erected a very fair Monument against the Chancel Wall, having this Inscription on it.
DIV2.Q:
In Memoriam charissimi Parentis EDOVARDI CLARKE de Ardington, Equitis aurati Monumentum hoc locari curavit JOHANNES CLARKE Armiger, ejusdem EDOVARDI filius ex clarissima faemina, Domina SUSANNA THOMAE TEMPLE Equitis Aurati & Baronetti filia, Quae una cum conjuge junctissimo resuscitaturi Domini adventum in isto dormitorio expectat.
In this Shrine together lye,
Wisdom matched with Sanctitye,
He a Clarke, she, without boast,
A Temple for the Holy Ghost. Absit ut glorier nisi in cruce.
DIV2.P: In the Chancel, on a Black Marble Grave-stone, near the Altar, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Henry Dewe, Gent. who married Martha, Daughter of Thomas Plott, of Upton, in the County of Berks, Gent. by whom he had two Sons, Henry and Bennet; and two Daughters, Mary and Elizabeth, who departed this Life the 3d of April, Ao. Domini, 1689. aged 57 Yeares.
DIV2.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.

TABLE.HEAD: Here lies the Bodies of Two Children of Henry Dewe, and Martha his Wife.

ROW.CELL: Henry their Son died in the 15th Yeare of his Age,
Mary their Dough∣ter dyed in the 5th Yeare of her Age,

DIV2.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth the Body of Richard Hobbis, Gent.
who departed this Life Aug. 28.

Anno
Dom. 1706.
Aetat. 62.

DIV2.P: On a Stone Tablet, like a Monument, just without the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: In Memorie of the charitable Giftes of Tho. Gryme, Rich. Fretwell, and Robert Batten, Benefactors to the Church of Ardington.
DIV2.P: Item, Thom. Gryme hath given a Tene∣ment to the Church-men of Ardington, for the Behoof of the Church, to remain per∣petually, Anno Dom. 1544.

Item, Rich. Fretwell hath given unto the Church, and Poor of Ardington, 30 l. to remain as a Stock for ever; part of the Use whereof to be disposed as followeth, 8 s. for the preaching of a Sermon upon the first Sunday in September yearly; and after the Sermon, 4 d. and a Penny Loaf
to every poor Body that lives by Alms of the said Parish, Anno Dom. 1618.

Item, Rob. Batten hath given in his Life-time a Silver Flaggon, and a Silver Plate, to remaine for the pious Use of the humble Communicants of the Church of Ardington, Anno Dom. 1633. B./. H. C. W. 1640.

DIV2.HEAD: East LOCKINGE,
DIV2.P: In the North Wall of the Chancel, East∣ward, is a small Monument fixed, having this Inscription.

Q.P: In Memoriam venerabilis Viri JACOBI GERARD in Artibus Magistri, & nuper Aedis Christi in Oxon. alumni; qui filius erat Gulielmi Gerrard, de Harrovia super Montem, in Comitatu Middlesexiae, Armigeri, & quondam Consilii Ducatus Lancastriae, Serenissimae Reginae Elizab. necnon potentissimo Principi Jacobo placide. In Domino obdormivit decimo Calendas Septembris, Anno Dom. 1628. An•. autem aetatis suae 35•▪ & hic requiescit in spem futurae Resurrectionis.
Monumentum hoc posuit amoris ergo, charissimus & gemellus frater ejus JOHANNES GERARD.

DIV2.P: Westward, in the said Wall, is another Monument erected, whereon is represent∣ed the Statue of a Woman kneeling at a Faldstool, under whom is this Inscription and Verses.
DIV2.Q:
In Memory of Mrs. MILLICENT, late Wife of Mr. JOHN GRACE, Vicar of Aldworth, in this County, and Daugh∣ter to EDWARD NEEDHAM, of Ilston, in the County of Leicester, Esquire; who was born the last Day of Novem∣ber, 1601. and dyed the 24th of August, 1633.
Had full-sunned Goodness ever met a Grave,
With this tombed Saint, it here a Tombe
might have;
Or could we Vertue with the Corps interr,
As it had lived, here it had lodged with her;
But what's Immortall earthly Rites prevents,
Yet selfe Memorials raise best Monuments.
She needes no Statue, here a Husband's woe
Eternity doth on it selfe bestow.
But that dryes up his Teares which crowned her Story,
She went the Roade of Saints, from Grace to Glory.
DIV2.P: Upon a Blue Marble Grave-stone laid in the middle of the Chancel, over a∣gainst the last mentioned Monument, un∣der the Figure of a Woman in her usual Habit, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Hunc tumulum maerens posuit frater JOHANNES NEEDHAM.

Here lyes Mrs. MARY NEEDHAM, youngest Daughter of Mr. EDWARD NEEDHAM, of Ilston, in the County of Leicester, Es{que} who was borne upon Friday the 22th of Aprill, 1611. and dyed upon Friday the 16 Day of January, 1628.

DIV2.P: At the East End of the South Isle lyes a fair Marble, whereon, in a Brass Plate, are engraven the Figures of a Man in a Gown, and a Woman in her usual Ha∣bit, under whose Feet is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here lyeth EDWARD KEATE, Gent. (the Third Son of WILLIAM KEATE, of East Hagborne, Gent.) and JOANE his Wife, the eldest Daughter of JOHN DOF, of this Parish, Gent. married An•. Domini, 1565. had Yssue by her EDWARD, WILLIAM, FRANCIS, and
JONN; ANNE, JANE, AGNES, CHRI∣STIAN, ELENOR, MARY, and DO∣ROTHY. He, aged 83 Yeares, dyed the first of May, 1624. She, aged 79 Yeares, dyed the last of February the same Yeare, leaving behind them good fames of Hospitality, and other Vertues.
DIV2.P: In the Chancel, on a fair Monument, is this Inscription.

Q.P: H. S. J. Reliquiae Thomae Upton, Olim. Coll. Om. An. Oxon. Socii.
This Line was intended, but not graved, Conspirantibus omnium suffragiis. Et inde Ad Rectoriam East Lockinge, Meritis ambientibus electi.
Cui praefuit tam Rector, quam exemplar, Vagos Opinione vel moribus Authoritate coercuit.
Errantes detinuit facunda comitate, Fregit insolentes, Omnium Benevolentiam sibi concilians, Successori obsequium.
Caeteras Virtutes a valente, Ab aegro, Lector, disce Patientiam, Nec languor gemitus, Nec sitis, nec onus hydropicum expressit, Tam pacatè quam vixit morituro.

Hic siste, Lector, Reliqua mortale sonant, Irruit simul tota morborum cohors, Et numero hostium, non viribus succumbens, Amantissimam tandem conjugem Aegerrime reliquit, Octobris die 10•. Aetatis Anno 50•. Domini, 1684.

DIV2.P: In the Church, on another Monument, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
H. S. J. Christophorus Minshull, natus Generosa familia in agro Sussexiensi: Oxonii educatus, ac ibidem Facultatis Stae. Theologiae nuper Bedellus, Armiger. Cur∣hoc in loco sepultus, quaeris? proh dolor! ad hanc villam iter Conficiens (iter eheu! quod ad sepulchrum duxit) non procul hinc ex equo violentius admisso decidit, delapso mors importuna viam & vitam intercepit. Obiit morte repentina die XXI Junii, An. Do. MDCLXXXI. Aetat. suae......
Franciscus defuncti Christophori frater pietatis ergo P.

DIV2.HEAD: WANTAGE,
DIV2.P: Is situate on a nameless Rivulet run∣ning into the River Ocke, is the Capital of the Hundred of Wanting, and is a handsome Market Town. It was called by the Saxons WANATING, and was in those Days a Royal Seat, in which King Alfred was born, who at his Death, by his Will, gave it to Alfrith. It re∣ceived its Charter for a Market 150 Years before the Conquest, by the Interest of Fulke Fitzwarin, who received it as a Re∣ward of some Military Performances, from Roger Bigod, Earl-Marshal. From the Fitzwarins it descended to the Bour∣chiers, Earls of Bath; from them it came to the Wrays, and was sold by one Sir Bourchier Wray to the noble and antient Family of the Doyly's, a well known Fa∣mily in Oxfordshire.

On the North Side of the Chancel is an Alabaster Monument erected, whereon are the Statues of Sir Fulke Fitzwarin, (one of the Knights of the Garter elected
in the Reign of King Edward the Third) as appears both by his Surcoat of Arms, and the Garter buckled about his left Leg; and the Figure of his Lady, both holding up their Hands in a devotional Posture, but without any Inscription.
In the middle of the Chancel lies a Grave-stone, whereon, under the Figures of a Man and Woman cut in Brass, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Hic jacet Rogerus Merlawe, & Ka∣terina Vror ejus; qui quidem Ro∣gerus obiit 12 Die Mensis Maii, Ano. Domini, 1460. Et dicta Ka∣terina Obiit tertio Die Januarii, Ano. Domini, 1459.
Quorum animabus propicietur Deus. Amen.

DIV2.P: On a Marble Grave-stone, in the said Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here lieth interred the Body of HELENA, Daughter of JOHN, Lord PAULET, Baron of Hinton St. George, in the County of Somerset, and Wife of WILLIAM WILMOT, Son and Heire of Sir GEORGE WILMOT, of Charleton,
in the County of Berks, Knight, who departed this Lyfe on the 12th Day of May, Anno Domini, 1651.
DIV2.P: In the Chancel, over the South Door, is a large Monument of Alabaster, and o∣ther fine Marble; on it are Three Figures, 1. Of a Gentleman in a long Peruke, with a Belt on, leaning on a Death's Head; under him, in Capitals, on a Black Mar∣ble, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: In Memory of William Wilmot, of Up-Lamborne, in the County of Berks, Es{que} Son of Sir George Wilmot, of Charleton, in the said County, Kt. which William dyed the 1st Day of November, 1684.
DIV2.P: Next stands a Child in a Shirt loose, resting his Hand on a Death's Head, and this Inscription in Capitals, on a White Marble.
DIV2.Q: In Memory of William, Son of the said William Wilmot, (by Mary his 3d Wife) who died in his Childhood the 22th Day of January, 1666.
DIV2.P: Next is a Woman with a Book in her Hand, and on her Head a loose Hood: All the Three Figures are of White Marble, supporting underneath Three Angels of Alabaster, with their Wings expanded, and this Inscription, on Black Marble, in Capitals.
DIV2.Q: Mary (the 3d Wife of the said William Wilmot, the Daughter of Richard Jervoyce, of Henard, in the County of Southampton, Es{que}) erected this Monument in Memory of her deceased Husband and Son.
DIV2.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone, in the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Gulielmus Wilmot, de Up-Lamborne, in Comitatu Berks, Armiger, obiit primo Die Novem. Anno 1684.
DIV2.P: On an old Black Marble Grave-stone, on the Floor, on a Brass Plate, is circum∣scribed this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Of your Charitie pray for the Soule of Maister William Ged∣dyng, late Vicar of All-Hallowe
Barkyng, which William decessed the XXX Day of December, the Yere of our Lord, MCCCCXII. On whose soule Thesu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: In the middle Ile, on an old Brass Plate, on a Grave-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Orate pro anima, Johannis Kylbi, qui obiit in vigilia Sci. Michis Archi. Anno Domini, MCCCCLXXXIo. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: In the South Ile, on a plain Grave-stone, in double Columns, is this Inscription.

LIST.ITEM: Here lyeth Frances, his Wife, who died the 12th of September, Anno Dom. 1684.
Here lyeth the Body of William Hard wick, Vicar of this Church, who dyed the 7th Day of November, Anno Domini, 1685.

Q.L: Here needs no Epitaph
To make them fam'd,
The Good are prais'd
When they are only nam'd.

DIV2.P: At the East End of the same Ile, on a Black Marble Grave-stone, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Francis Grove, of Grove, in this Parish, Gent. He departed this Life the 8th Jan. Ao. Do. 1697. in the 53d Yeare of his Age.
DIV2.P: On a small square Piece of Black Mar∣ble, like a Gravestone, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here lieth the Body of Hannah Tub, who departed this Life, July the 21. 1711. Aged 8 Weekes.
Not Innocence, nor Parent's Love,
Nor Tears, could stay my quick remove.
DIV2.P: On a Marble Monument set in the North Wall of the Chancel, is this In∣scription.
DIV2.Q:
Videte in tumulis proximos ut in amore vivos, JOHANNEM WILSON Generosum, & MARIAM Uxorem ejus, & MATILDAM filiam ejus unicom: Quorum Memoriae suaeque pietatis Monumentum hoc
posuit EDWARDUS WILSON, Sacrae Theologiae Baccalaureus, bujus Ecclesiae pro tempore Patronus. Qui de unâ fidelium Resurrectione certus cum iis intumulari curavit. O homo moreris!
DIV2.P: On a Grave-stone in the said North Ile, is the Pourtraiture of a Knight in Armour; his Feet resting on a Lion, and his Head upon his Helm: Under his Feet is the following Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: In gracia & misericordia Dei, hic jacet Ivo Fitzwarin, Miles, qui obiit sexto die Mensis Septembris, An•. Domini, 1414. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: Towards the South Side of this Ile lies a Grave-stone, whereon are the Fi∣gures of a Man and Woman, and under their Feet this Inscription.

Q.P:
Here lyeth buried WILLIAM WILMOT, Gent. who died the.... Day of Decemb. An•. Domini, 1618. He married CICILY HYDE, one of the Daughters
of HEUGH HYDE, of Letcombe Regis, Esquire, by whome he had six Children, two Sons, HEUGH and GEORGE WILMOT; and four Daughters, CICILYE, MARTHA, FRAUNCES, and BRIDGET WILMOT.

Whilst he lived he was to his Superi∣ours respective, to his Equalls friendly, to his Inferiours compassionate, to the Poore charitable, who after 76 Yeares Travell in this World, by a vertueous Departure recommended his Soule to the Mercy of his Saviour; in Memory whereof, his Sonns in Law, THOMAS GARRARD, and THOMAS TEMPEST, have placed this Stone as a Monument to his Posterity, the 20th Day of June, A•. 1619.

DIV2.P: This Circumscription following is upon the same Stone.
DIV2.Q: vevit auxilium meum. In ma∣nus tuas, Domine, commendo spiritum meum. Redemisti me sanguine tuo Domine. Deus veritatis. In te▪ Domine, speravi, non confundar in aeternum.
DIV2.P: In the South Ile of the Church is a Grave-stone, whereon, on a Brass Plate, are the Figures of a Man in a Gown, and his two Wives, and under them this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Pray for the Soulles of Water Tawbot, and Alys his Wife; which Water decessyd the 18th Day of A∣prill, in the Yere of our Lord, 1522. On whose Soule Ihesu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: Under the Man are the Figures of five Sons, and under the Woman of four Daughters.

DIV2.HEAD: LAMBORNE,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Deanery of New∣bury; Dean of St. Paul's Church, in Lon∣don, Patron; Incumbent, the Reverend Mr. Taylor.

This Place was the Inheritance of Willi∣am Essex, Es{que} descended from an honour∣able, and most antient Family of that
Name in the County of Essex; of which Family, Wynmarke, Robert, and Swane, lived successively in greater Honour and Reputation than any other Nobles in that County, before the Normans enter'd this Realm. An Ancestor of this William, one Sir William Essex, Knight, Son and Heir of Tho. Essex, Es{que} and Elizabeth, Daugh∣ter of William Essex, Under-Treasurer of England to King Edw. IV. married Eliza∣beth, Daughter and Heir of Thomas Ro∣gers, of Lamborne and Benham, Es{que} whose Ancestor, John Rogers, married Elizabeth, Daughter and Heir of John Shotesbroke, of Becoat, Es{que} whose Father, Sir Gilbert Shotesbroke, Knight, married Elizabeth, Daughter and Heir of Sir Hinion Standon, of Standon, in the County of Stafford, Knt. Lamborne, Becoate, and Standon is, with divers other Lands, the Inheritance of this Family at this Day.
In the middle Ile, under the Busto's of a Man and Woman to the Middle, engra∣ved in Brass Plates, and set on a Grave-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Jone de Estbury, et Agnes, sa fem∣me gysent ici, Dieu de leur ames eit Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: On a raised Monument, on the North Side of the high Altar, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
THOMAS GARRARD tooke to Wife AGNES BLAGRAVE, by whome he had Yssue WILLIAM and ELIZABETH; AGNES, the first Wife of Thomas Gar∣rard, departed this Lyfe the 28th of July, 1556. Thomas Garrard, her Husband, departed the 24th of Decem∣ber, 1583. William Garrard, their Son, most faithfully, in Memory of them both, caused this Monument to be erect∣ed; which William departed this Life the 10th of July, 1608.
Three Children more, at one Birth, Agnes had,
Were all baptized, with her in one Grave layd.
DIV2.P: Upon a Grave-stone near the former Monument, under the Figures of a Man and Woman, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here lyeth THOMAS GARRRAD, Gent. the first Sonne of THOMAS GARRARD, (in the Monument on the Wall above-written) by ALICE, his second Wife, who dyed the 9th of August, Anno Domini, 1619. and ANNE his Wife, the Daughter of JOHN TUTT, Esquire, who died the 20th of January, 1610.
and in remembrance of them, THOMAS GARRARD, their Son, hath placed this Marble Stone over them.
DIV2.P: At the End of a Marble Monument raised upon Four Pillars, on the South Side of the Chancel, is this Inscription cut in Brass.

Q.P: Here lyeth ROGER GARRARD Gent. and ELIZABETH his Wife, whose Bodies rest in the earth, their Mother, and whose Soules do live with God, their Father, which said Roger being of the Age of 66 Years, dyed 1631.
Mors mihi lucrum. Hodie mihi, cras tibi.
Q.L: I am but Earth, and yet am God's Creature,
My Sins are greate, and yet God's Mercies greater.
For I believe in Christ his Son, and by him hope to be saved.

DIV2.HEAD: Elizabeth Garrard

Q.L: Uxor Garrardi, jacet hic, quae nata Blagravi,
Uni aetate fuit, nulla pietate secunda.
Nam talis erat, qualis erat talem,
Suus Vir nunquam vidit, Roger Garrard.

DIV2.P:
On the South Side of the Church is built a fair Chapel, and very well beauti∣fied, in the middle whereof is a large raised Monument of Grey Marble, whose Top-stone bears on a Brass Plate the fol∣lowing
lowing Inscription round the Figure of a Person in Armour holding up his Hands in a devout Posture.
DIV2.Q: Hi jacet Johannes Estbury, Ar∣miger, fundator istius nove ca∣pelle a cantarie ac consanguineus & heres Johannis........... Predict. ac fundator hujus vete∣ris capelle qui obiit... viii. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: On a Scrowl, near the Figure, are these Words.
DIV2.Q: Pater de celis, Deus, miserere nobis.
DIV2.P: In the East Window, painted on the Glass, is the Picture of the Founder kneel∣ing, having only a winding Sheet over him, and this Scrowl issuing out of his Mouth.
DIV2.Q: Mundi salvator, sis michi propitiator.
DIV2.P:
In a Chapel situated between the South Chapel and the Chancel, are Plates of Brass, having the Figures of two Persons
to the middle, and set in a Grave-stone, under which is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Johannes Estbury, Armi∣ger, fundator Cantarie Sancte Marie iste Capelle, qui Obiit 25 Die octob. An• d. Domini, 1372. Et Thomas filius ejus, Armiger, qui obiit... Die Mensis... A•. Domini, MCCCC... Quorum animabus propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: On another Plate of Brass, fixed in a Grave-stone, follows this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Johannes Estbury, & Agnes Vxor ejus, qui obiit penultimo Die Mensis Septembris, An•. Do∣mini, Millimo CCCCXXXVIII. Quorum animabus propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: On another Brass Plate, fixed on a Grave-stone, is the following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Johanna Tremayn, filia Johannis Estbury senioris, que obiit.... Die Mensis... An. Domini, Millimo CCCC.... Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: On another Brass Plate, fixed in a Grave-stone, is the following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: To the living Memory of her deare Husband, ROGER SEYMORE, of In∣holt, in Lamborne Woodlands, Gent. Lieutenant to the Traine-Band, who died the 7th Day of Aprill, 1631. and of his Age 35, was this Stone placed by ANNE, his first Wife, of whome he had 3 Sons, to whose Care he com∣mitted them at his decease.
DIV2.P: In the middle of the Chapel, on the North Side of the Chancel, is a fair raised Monument, whereon lye the Statues in Full Proportion, according to the Life, of a Knight and his Lady; he in his Surcoat of Arms over his Armour, resting his Head on a Helmet and Crest, viz. an Eagle's Head with a Firebrand in his Mouth, and his Feet on Dolphin bowed; she in her usual Habit and Attire, her Feet resting on a Goat with Wings, and this Epitaph circumscribed on the Ledge thereof.
DIV2.Q:
Here lyeth the Bodies of Thomas Effex, Knight, who deceased the 29th Day of August, in the Yere of our
Lord God, One Thousand Five Hun∣dred Fifty and Eight; and Dame Margaret his Wife.
DIV2.P: On the North Side of the Church stands an Hospital, on the right Hand of whose Entrance, on a Brass Plate, fixed in the Wall, are the following Verses.

Q.L: Hec nova structura retinens habitacula plura,
Sit permansura per tempora longa futura,
Nam cecis simul & claudis domus ista beata,
Pauperibus non divitibus fuit edificata.
Quam qui dona vit et in evum perpetua vit,
Hunc fundatorem vsos Eitbury scite Johannem.
Et domus ista Dei, debet per secula dicit
Cujus in his finis, patet hic manifesta figurei 1485.
Est domus ista Dei, pacis, precis, & requiei,
Quas tibi concedat, qui vivit & ethere regnat.

DIV2.P: The Stream that washes this Town, is called Lamborn River, which, contrary to the Nature of all other Rivers, is ever high in the Summer, and so low in the Winter, that it is entirely lost. It leaves this Place about Michaelmass, and some∣times before; but the sooner it goes, the Country People observe, that the cheaper Corn is that Season. It is thus described by the excellent Translator of Dubarta's Weeks, Mr. Joseph Sylvester, who lived here for many Years.

Q.L: And little Lambes-Bourn, tho' thou match not Lers,
Nor hadst the Honour of Dubarta's Verse;
If mine have any, thou must needs partake,
Both for thine Own, and for thine Owner's sake.
All Summer long (while all thy Sisters shrink)
Then of thy Waters Thousands daily drink;
Besides that Water, which in hast doth run
To wash the Feet of Chaucer's Donnington.
But, while the rest are full unto the top,
All Winter long, thou dost not shew a drop,
Nor sends a Doit of needless Subsidy,
To cram the Kennet's wantless Treasury;
Before her Store be spent, and Springs be staid,
Then, thou alone, thou lend'st a liberal aid;
Teaching thy wealthy Neighbours (mine of late)
How, when, and where to right participate
Their Streams of Comfort to the Poor that pine,
And not to grease still the to greasy Swine;
Neither for Fame, for Form (when others do)
To give a Morsel, or a Mite or two;
But severally, and of a selfly Motion,
When others miss, to give the most Devotion.

DIV2.HEAD: HUNGERFORD.
DIV2.P:
This Town, washed by the River Ken∣net, is situate in the Hundred of Kentbury, and Deanery of Newbury; is a Thorough∣fare in the Road from London to Bath, Bri∣stol,
and the Western Part of England; is remarkable for excellent Trouts and Craw∣fish; was formerly called Ingleford Char∣nam-street. This small Market-Town gave both Name and Title to the noble and antient Family of Hungerford's, of which I could say much, were it not al∣ready fully mentioned in Sir William Dug∣dale's Baronage of England. The Con∣stable of this Place, elected annually, is Lord of this Manor, which he holds im∣mediately of the Crown. They preserve here a Horn, which contains about a Quart, which, by the Inscription on it, appears to have been the Benefaction of John of Gaunt, who procured them a Grant of the Riall Fishing, as they term it, in a cer∣tain Part of the River Kennet. The Right of Presentation to this Vicaridge is in the Dean and Chapter of Windsor; the Reve∣rend Mr. Wells is present Incumbent.
On a Grave-stone, lying in the Body of the Church, is this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q:
Here lyeth the Body of FRANCIS GOD∣DARD, of Standen Hussey, in the County of Wilts, Es{que} Son of THOMAS GODDARD, of the said Standen, Es{que} who deceased the 15th of January, 1652. The said Francis had to Wife
SARAH, the Daughter of Sir ANTHO∣NY HUNGERFORD, of Black-Borton, in the County of Oxford, Knight, by whome he had Yssue two Sonns, ED∣WARD and FRANCIS, and three Daugh∣ters, MARGARET, SARAH, and KA∣THERINE, whereof Margaret and Katherine deceased before their Fa∣ther; the other Three yet survive.
DIV2.P: Engraven in a large Plate of Brass, fastened in an Arch cut into the South Wall, under the South Window of a Cha∣pel on the South Side of the Church, in old Saxon Characters, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Pry pour Mons. Robert de Hungerford, tant cum it vivera, Et pour l'alme de ly appressa mort priere: Synk Cents et sinquante jours de pardon avera grante de quatorse et veoques tant come il fust en vie: per quei en noum de charite: Pater et Ave.
DIV2.P: Round, on the same Stone, in Brass, in a circular manner, is this Inscription in Saxon Characters.
DIV2.Q:
Quod de terra surrecturus fum quum in carne mea videbo Deum salvatorem.
Quum nos Pater, Filius, ac Spiritus Sanctus nos un. Quum non.... suam operam judicabis.
DIV2.P: In an inner Circle is this Inscription.

Q.HI: Per Dei Patris Potentiam. Per Filii Sapientiam. Per Sancti Spiritus... vitam possidere beatem.

DIV2.P: In the South Window, under some Coats of Arms, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: ...... Hungerford, de Cosham, in Com. Wilts,..... genitus Illustrissimi ANTHONII....... de Black-Burton, in Comit atu.. ... factus Miles honor abilis... ... primo Caroli Regis, quo ... erat Rex, July 19, A•. Dumini, 1629.
DIV2.P: Under another Escotchaon, whose Arms are now broke our, remains this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: MARGARETA natu minor & cohaeres venerabilis GULIELMI HOLLIDAIE, Armigeri Londinensis Civis & Al∣dermanni, Uxor dicti EDVARDI HUN∣GERFORD, de Cosham, Balnei Ordi∣nis Militis, July 19, 1629.

DIV2.HEAD: SHAWBONE,
DIV2.P: In the North Side of the Chancel is a Monument raised against the Wall, where lyes the Statue of a Man in Armour, at full length, with a Gold Chain about his Neck, and on the foreside this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Pray ye all for the Sole of FRANCIS CHOKE, deceased in the Year of our Lord, 1561. in the 14 Day.
DIV2.P: On the South Side of the Church-yard, on a Blue Grave-done, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Aetatis suae, 74, An•. Domini, 1636.
Mons fuer am vegeto dum mens in corpore mansit, Mens abit ad Dominum, mons abit ad cineres. In mortem cineres Domino redeunte redibunt, Expecto hoc oriens: hoc meditor moriens.
ROLANDUS HILL, senio, morboque languidus sed fide speque fortis de me ipse scripsi ac sepulchro inscribendum mandavi.

DIV2.HEAD: INKPEN,
DIV2.P: Is a Rectory in the Deanery of New∣hury. Patron the Warden Winchester College; Incumbent the Reverend Mr. Brickington.
On the North Side of the Chancel lyes the Statue of a Knight cross-legged, arm∣ed in Male, and a short Coat over it; he holds a deep Shield on his left Arm, and his right seems drawing a Sword.

DIV2.HEAD: HAMPSTED-MARSHALL.
DIV2.P: This Village was so called, because it formerly belonged to the Earl Marshal of England, and was held by the Tenure of the Rod of the Marshallsea. Here was a fine Seat, built by Sir Thomas Parry, Trea∣surer of the Houshold to Queen Elizabeth. Not many Years since, the late Lord Cra∣ven began another Seat, about which there was spent much Money, though it never was finished. It is pleasantly si∣tuated on an Eminencey, and has a fine Prospect. It is in the Deanery of New∣hurry; Patron Lord Craven; Incumbent the Reverend Mr. Browne.
At the Entrance into the Chancel, on the South Side, is this Inscription follow∣ing on a Grave-stone.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth that good and godly Man, Mr. RICHARD SMITH, of Hampstedd, of the Age of 67 Yeares, deceased the 29th of August, 1637. His Will was, not to be moved out of bis Tombe till the Day of Doome; and he hath given 6 s. 8d. for a Sermon to be preached on Munday in Whitson Weeke for ever; and he hath given 10 s. to the Poore of this Place of Hamsted for ever.
DIV2.P: Under the South Window, in the Chan∣cel, lyes the Body of Sir Balthazar Ger∣bier, but there is no Stone, or Memorial, erected for, or laid over him.

DIV2.HEAD: West WOODHEY.
DIV2.P:
This Place was formerly the Estate of the Barons of St. Amand, from whom it descended, by Marriage, to Gerard de Braybroke, whose eldest Grand-Daughter transferred it by an inter-Marriage with
William Beauchamp, who was summoned to Parliament, An. 27 Hen. VI. by the Name of Beauchamp of St. Amand. In the 35th of the same King, on William's Death, his Son Richard succeeded, who died without lawful Issue 23 Hen. VII. when he made a Settlement of the largest Part of his Estate upon his natural Son, Anthony St. Amand.
On a Black Marble set in the Wall, directly under the East Window of the Chancel, is this Inscription.
The Family have sold this Estate to one.....Aflick, a Merchant of London.

DIV2.HEAD: KENTBURY.
DIV2.P: This is a large Parish, containing seve∣ral Tythings. Sir Jemmatt Raymond is Lord of that Part of the Manor wher the Church stands, and Patron; as also of Barton, just on the other Side of the River, where he hath a Seat. It is a Vicaridge in the Deanery of Newbury; Incumbent, the Reverend Mr. Lloyd.
In the Chancel, on Brass Plates upon a flat Grave-stone, are the Pourtraitures of a Man in a Gown, and a Woman in a Hat; and under them is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Mr. JOHN GUNTER, and ALICE, his Wife, being full as of Years, so of Boun∣ty and Charity, are gathered to their Fathers in Peace. He was here buri∣ed, the 2d of January, 1624. aged 89
Yeares. She was buried at Cicester, in the County of Gloucester, with the like Monument, the 18th of March, An•. Domini, 1626. aged 86 Yeares. Jos. Plat, eorundem Gener. & Execu∣tor hoc posuit.
DIV2.P: Arms on it, Sable, 3 Sinifter Gaunt∣lets, Arg. a Crescent dif. On an Atchieve∣ment are the same Arms in a Lozenge, empaling, Ar. 3▪ Battle-Axes Sab.
Engraved on another Grave-stone is this Inscription.
The Arms of Gunter are also upon this.
In the Church, on a Monument fixed to the East Wall is the following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of PHILIP JEM∣MET, Es{que} sometime Alderman of the City of London, who departed this Life the 17th of June, in the Yeare of our Lord, 1678. aged 63.
DIV2.P: Jemmet's Arms on this, Parry per Chevron, Gul. and Sa. 3 Unicorns Heads erased, Or, empaling, Ar. a Griffin Ram∣pant, Sa. The Crest, a Unicorn's Head, Or, winged and armed Sa.
Raymond's Arms on Streamers, Az. a Spread Eagle, Ermine, on a Chief em∣batled, Ar. 3.
On another, Raymond empaling, Gul. a Griffon pass. and a Chief, Or, a Crescent, dif. (Sir Jemmet Raymond married the Daughter of Sir George Brown, as I am informed.)
On another, Raymond quartering Jem∣met, empaling the Griffin Passant, quar∣tering, Az. a Chevron betwixt 3.....

DIV2.HEAD: Great SHEFFORD.
DIV2.P: This Manor came to the Family of Browne, (a younger House of my Lord Viscount Montacute) by Marriage with an Heiress of the Family of Bruges. They are also Patrons to the Rectory; the pre∣sent Rector is the Reverend Mr. Samuel Lynton, sometime of Pembroke College in Oxford.
The East Window of the Chancel, and South Window of the Church, were made by Mr. Reginald Kentwood.
In the East Window of the Chancel are these Arms, Gul. 3 Roses, Ermine.
At the bottom of the Window there only remains
DIV2.Q: Ke... qui fieri fecit.
DIV2.P: In the Chancel, on an Altar Monu∣ment, adjoyning to the South Wall, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Sir George Browne, Knight of the honourable Or∣der of the Bath, eldest Sonne of George Browne, Es{que}, who dyed the 5th of Dec. An. Domini, 1678.
DIV2.P: Arms on this are, Browne quartering Montacute, with a Crescent dif. The Crest a Spread Eagle.
On a flat Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here lyeth the Body of John Yeat, Son of Charles Yeat, of Lyford, Es{que}; and Mary, his Wife. Charles, the Grand∣son of George Browne, of this Parish, Es{que}; and Mary, the Daughter of Tho∣mas Wollapot, of Sutton, Es{que} both of the County of Berks. He dyed in
his Infancy the 26th of June, An. Domini, 1688.
DIV2.P: On another Grave-stone is the follow∣ing Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Eliz. Browne, who departed this Life, Nov. 27. An. Domini, 1662. She was Sister to Sir George Browne, and died a Maid.
DIV2.P: On another Grave-stone is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Henry Browne, who departed this Life the 19th of March, 1668. He was Brother to Sir George, and died unmarried.
DIV2.P: On another Grave-stone is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth Mary Wadman, Daugh∣ter of Robert Wadman, Es{que} and of Hannah his Wife. She dyed the 21th Day of May, 1687. in the 3d Year of her Age.

DIV2.HEAD: East, or Little SHELFORD,
DIV2.P: Is in the Hundred of Kentbury, a Rec∣tory in the Deanery of Newbury; Patron Robert Packer, Es{que} Incumbent, the Reve∣rend Dr. Stratford.

On the North Wall of the Chancel is erected a Grey Marble Monument, Altar wise, in which are drawn, upon several Brass Plates fixed thereto, the Figures following, viz. a Man kneeling at a Fald∣stool in Armour, and out of his Mouth iffues this Scrowl.
DIV2.Q: Deus, misereatur nottri & benedicat nobis.
DIV2.P: A Woman drest in the Habit of her Times, kneeling after the same manner, facing the Man, with this Inscription on a Scrowl.
DIV2.Q: Illuminet vultum suum super nos.
DIV2.P: Behind the Man are Three Sons, and behind the Woman Four Daughters, and under the Figures is this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Here, under this Combe, lyeth buried JOHN PETIPLACE, Esquire, and DOROTHY his Wife; which John deceassyd the 11th Day of October, A•. Domini, 1524. for whose Soule, of your Charitie, say a Pater Noster and an Abe.
DIV2.P: On the South Side of the Chancel lyes a Grave-stone, from whence all the in∣scribed Brass is stolen but this.
DIV2.Q: ....... decessed the 18th Day of November, in the Yeare of our Lord, 1558.
DIV2.P: On the South Side of the Chancel is a very fair raised Tomb, whereon lyes the Statue of a Man in Armour (much like that once upon John of Gaunt's Tomb in St. Paul's Cathedral, London.) On a Wreath on his Helm, lying under his Head, is his Crest, viz. an Eagle's Head, and his Feet resting on a Lion. His Lady lyes by his Right Side, drest in the Habit of the Times in which she lived, without any Inscription by which any Discovery can be made to whom it belonged.

DIV2.HEAD: Little FAWLEY,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Deanery of New∣bury; has been long the Inheritance of the Family of Moore, one of whom, Sir Ri∣chard Moore, is present Patron, Incum∣bent, the Reverend Mr. Holmes.
On the South Side of the East Window, in the Chancel, is a Plate of Brass, bear∣ing a Woman kneeling, with her Son near her, and this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
A Monument erected by HUMFRY GUNTER, Gent. to the Memory of his deare Wife, MARY, the Daughter of THOMAS CRESSWELL, Gent. who at the Age of 36 Yeares left him and one Son the 6 of Febr. A•. 1621.
Grace, Nature, Love, and all good Parts in one,
Which Lyfe displaid, Death hides within a Tombe,
Where lyeth a faithfull Soule, an holy Heart,
A Mary right, who chose the better Part.
Which Choice she fully joyed, Joy is her Lott,
The happy Goale she run for she hath gott.
My mournefull Soule doth wish it where thou art,
Till the farewell, sweet Saint, my Heart, my Heart!
DIV2.P: Upon a Marble Grave-stone, laid un∣der the Communion Table, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here resteth the Body of MARY BE∣VERLEY, Wife of WILLIAM BEVER∣LEY, of Chaneho, in the County of Bedford, Esquire, after whose decease she lived in her Widdowhood 57 Yeares, and dyed the 14th of Aprill, 1658. aged 80 Yeares, in pious Memory of whome, Dame ELIZABETH MORE, of South Fally, in Berks, Widdow, and Daughter of the said Mary, hath placed this.

DIV2.HEAD: LETCOMBE-REGIS,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Deanery of Abington; Incumbent, the Reverend Mr. Hunsdon.
On a raised Tomb, in the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Under, or near this Tomb, lieth the Bodies of George Goodlake, Gent. and Ann, his Wife, who was Daughter of Sir Charles Wiseman, Kt.
She was buryed the 29th of June, 1638. and he Feb. the 26. 1644. Here lieth interred the Body of Thomas Goodlake, Gent. the Son of George Goodlake, who deceased February the 15th. Anno Dom. 169¾. aged 60 Years, who married Ann, the Daughter of Edmond Wiseman, of Spearsholt Court in the County of Berks, Es{que}
DIV2.P: On the Ground, on a Black Marble Grave-stone, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth interr'd the Bodys of Alexander Fettyplace, of Letcombe-Regis, Gent. and Edmond Fettyplace, of the Middle Temple, London, Es{que} both died in October, A. D. 1712.

Alexander, Edmond,
Aged
55.
48.

DIV2.P: Upon a rough Stone, in the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here lieth the Body of Mr. Edward Far∣mer, late Vicar of this Parish, deceased, who was buried the
22d Day of November, in the Year of Lord, 1675.
DIV2.P: Upon a rough Stone, in the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Thomas Champion, of the Middle Temple, London, Gent. Sonne of Maister George Champion, of Wantage, who departed this Life the last Daye of September, Anno Domini, 1668.
DIV2.P: On a Black Marble Stone is the fol∣lowing Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
H. S. E. Johannes Hunsdon, Hujus Ecclesiae, circiter quadringinta Annos, Fidelis Pastor, Qui pro feliciori hanc vitam mutavit, Die 30 Martii, Anno Dom. 1715. Aetatis suae 68. In eodem Sepulchro conduntur Martha & Margaretae, Fil. Amab. Quae teneris Annis desiderabantur,
Martha, obiit 28 Maii, 1694. Margareta, mortua est, 2 Nov. 1698. Ut magnus erga Virum & filias Amor Innotesceret. Hunc lapidem, maerens posuit, Martha, Conjux & Mater amantiss.
DIV2.P: On a Monument, fixed to the Wall near the Altar, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Anne Grove, the Daughter of Robert, and Margaret Grove, of Baulking, Gent. deceased, who departed this Life the 19th Day of January, Anno 1669. hopeing for a glorious Resurrection with the just, aged 27.
DIV2.P: On the same Wall is a small Monument with this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Vita Bulla. In Memory of Martha and Margarett, Daughters of John Hunsdon, Vicar, and Martha his Wife, who deceased in the 3d Year of their Age,
viz.
Martha, May 28. A. D. 1694.
Margarett, Nov. 28. 1698.
If Youth, nor Innocence could save,
These pretty Infants from the Grave;
Reader, expect not for to find
A better House, a Fate more kind.
DIV2.P: In a Chest, in this Church, is preserved a Brass Plate, which is broke in two Pieces, and when joyned together, this Inscripti∣on may be gathered from it.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth William Plokenet, Gen∣tilman, otherwise called William Yong, and Margarete his Wyfe, late the Wyfe of John York, Gen∣tilman; the whyche Margarete dyed the XXIIII. Day of Aprilis, the Yere of our Lord God, Ao. MCCCCLXIII. On whos Sowlys God have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: Towards the lower End of the East Window, is painted in the Glass, a Man with a Horn hanging behind him, and his Wife near him, both of them kneel∣ing; under them is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Orate pro animabus Johannis Mer∣mylle, & Alicie Vxoris ejus.
DIV2.P: On a Brass Plate set in a small Grave-stone, is the Figure of a Woman engra∣ved, at whose Feet is this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Alicia Estbury, filia Jo∣hannis Estbury, & Agnetis.......

DIV2.HEAD: BRIGHT WALTON,
DIV2.P: In the Chancel, on a Grave-stone, are the Figures of a Man in a Gown, and a Woman in her usual Habit, cut in Brass Plates, and over their Heads are these Verses.

Q.L: Cujus, dum virit, famam vel lingoa maligua
Carpere se voluit, leere non valuit
Post Christi virtute labores,
Occult victor mortis, & inviie.

DIV2.P: Under their Feet is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Qui passs, pro nobis, miserere nobis.
Hic jacet JACOBUS BRAYBROOKE, Armiger, qui obiit septimo Die Maii, Anno Domini, 1590. & MARTHA Vxor ejus.
DIV2.P: Under all are the Figures of Three Sons and Four Daughters.
On a Marble Grave-stone, under the Figures of a Man, and his Wife laid in the middle of the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: WILLIAM BRAYBOOKE, Esquire, deceased in the Yeare 1592. who had to Wife Margaret, Daughter of RICHARD MIDLEMOE, also Esquire, and had Yssue one only Son RICHARD BRAYBROOKE, who caused this Monument to be made.
DIV2.P: Under the Figure of an Ecclesiastick in his Habit, on a Brass Plate fixed in the South Wall, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Of your Charite pray for the Soule of Master Thomas Yonge, sometyme Parson of this Church▪ and Commissarie of Barkeshire; ui obiit octavo Die Septembris, Ano Domini, 1525.
DIV2.P: In the Cieling of this Church, over the High Altar, are in every Pane the Letters T. I. painted in them.
Upon a Brass Plate fixed in a Marble, under the Figures of a Man in a Gown, with his Wife, and Son between them, in their usual Habits, with this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Of your Charitie pray for the Soules of John Newman, and Elyn his Wife, and Thomas their Son; which John decessyd the 8th Day of Aprill, in the Yere of our Lord God, One Thousand Five Hundred and Seaventeen. On whose Soules Ihesu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: In the Chest standing in the Chancel, is laid up a Brass Plate, formerly taken from a Grave-stone, bearing the Pourtrai∣ture of an Ecclesiastick in his Priestly Vestments, and under him this Inscripti∣on following.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Johannes Young, & Ag∣neta Vxor ejus, qui quidem Jo∣hannes obiit..... Die..... An. Domini, 1476. Quorum ani∣mabus propicietur Deus. Amen.

DIV2.HEAD: CHADLEWORTH,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Deanery of New∣bury; Patrons the Dean and Chapter of Westminster; Incumbent, the Reverend Mr. Pocock.
In the North Wall of the Chancel is a small Monument with this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Dorothy Nel∣son, Wife of William Nelson, Es{que} chief Prothonotary of the Common Pleas, who departed this Life the last Day of Aprill, in the Yeare of our Lord God, 1619. being of the Age of 86 Yeares, and bad Yssue 7 Children.
DIV2.P: Above the Inscription is her Figure kneeling, and behind her 5 Sons and 2 Daughters; (but here is a mistake, for I was informed that she had but one Son) un∣derneath the Inscription are these Verses.

Q.L: It was not many Yeares that made me good,
Neither was it the Vigour of my Blood;
For if so, then my Goodness might have pass'd,
And as I did, have ceased to be at last,
But 'twas the Grace my Maker did inshrine.
As my Soule now amongst the chosen blest,
Under this Stone although my Bones do rest.

DIV2.P: On the same Monument is represent∣ed another Woman kneeling at a Fald∣stool, having the Figures of four Sons, and two Daughters behind her, with this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Under this Tombe lyeth interred the Body of Mary Nelson, Daughter of Stephen Ducket, Esquire, and Wife of Thomas Nelson, of this Parish, Esq; who on the 13th of March, A°. Dom. 1618. exchanged thys Lyfe for a bet∣ter, being of the Age of 30 Yeares, and had Yssue Seaven Children.
If thou Religious art that passeth by,
Stay and read on; as thou art, so was I.
If thou art blest with Children, and doest crave
In God's true Feare, them trained up to have,
Reade on againe, and to thy selfe thus tell,
Here she dothlye that was my Parible;
Or art thou Bonnteous, Hospitable, Free,
Beloved of all, and they beloved of thee,
Meeke, full of Mercy, and so truly good,
As Flesh can be, and sprung of gentle Blood;
If thou art so, to thyne owne deare selfe say,
Who her Grave my Monument did lay?
But if to those, thou knowst thy self but Chass,
Pass on thy Way, read not my Epitaph.
DIV2.P: On the South Side of the Church∣yard, on a raised Tomb-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here iyeth buried the Body of MAR∣GARET BLANDY, first Wife of ADAM BLANDY, who departed this Lyfe the 3d Day of Dec. A°. Domini, 1593. and had Yssue 16 Children.
DIV2.P: On a Grave-stone, near adjoyning, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyes buried the Body of ANNE BLANDY, second Wife of ADAM BLAN∣DY, who departed this Lyfe the 19th of October, An°. Domini, 1600.
DIV2.P: On a Grave-stone, lying near Margaret Blandy's Stone, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth buried the Body of ADAM BLANDY, eldest Son of ADAM BLAN∣DY, who departed this Lyfe the 19th of March, An°. Domini, 1619.
DIV2.P:
At the Foot of a fair raised arched Monument is the following Inscription
engraven, next to the last mentioned Grave-stone.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of ADAM BLAN∣DY, of Inglewood, the Son of JOHN BLANDY, of Letcombe-Basset, and entombed at the Charge of KATHERINE his Wife............
DIV2.P: At the Foot of another arched Monu∣ment, adjoyning, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of EDWARD BLANDY, Citizen of London, who ..........

DIV2.HEAD: PEYSEMORE,
DIV2.P: Is a Rectory in the Hundred of Fair∣cross, and Deanery of Newbury. Patron Mr. Sherley; Incumbent, the Reverend Mr. Sherley.
In the Chancel, on a Brass Plate fixed to a Grave-stone, is this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q:
Here lyeth the Body of THOMAS STAMPE, of this Parish, Gent. He departed this World, the 4th Day of June, 1636. at the Age of 72 Yeares.
I am the Stone that here am set to show,
That Thomas Stampe lyes here interr'd below,
Whose Love unto this Place, the World, the Poore,
Renowned him here, now crowne him evermore.
A private Lyfe, which he so much desired,
Obscured his Vertues, made him less admired;
This, for Conclusion, to his Praise belongs,
He suffered much; free from the guilt of Wrongs.

DIV2.HEAD: HAMSTED-NORRIS.
DIV2.P: So called from the noble and antient Family Norris's, who have some Estate here; one of whom, James Norris, Es{que} was High-Sheriff of Oxfordshire in 1715. It is a Vicaridge situate in the Hundred of Fair-cross, and Deanery of Newbury. Pa∣tron is John Dod, of the Inner Temple, in London, Esq; Member of Parliament for the City of Wells, in Somersetshire; In∣cumbent, the Reverend Mr. Davis.
Under the Figure of a Man in a short Gown, on a Brass Plate fixed to a Grave-stone, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Hic jacet Ricardus Smert, qui obiit 23 Die Maii, 1468.
Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.

DIV2.P: On another Brass Plate, in a Marble near adjoyning, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Johannes Pocock, qui obiit 21 Die Mensis Junii, An. Domini, Millimo CCCCLXXXXIII. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.

DIV2.HEAD: YATTENDON,
DIV2.P: Is a Rectory, and part of the Estate of the Norris's lyes about a Mile from Ham∣sted, in the same Hundred and Deanery. Patron, James Norris, Es{que} Incumbent, the Reverend Mr. Pennington.

At the Foot of the East Window, on the left Hand, are the Pictures, in Glass, of a Man in a short Blue Fur Gown, and two Women in Blue Gowns, kneel∣ing also behind him, and behind them two Sons and two Daughters. The like Figures seem to have been painted at the right Hand of the said Window, opposite to the former. At the bottom of the Window, on the Glass, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Orate pro vono statu Johannis... CCCC....... & Regis prefat. XXXII.
DIV2.P: In the South Windows of the Chancel is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Orate pro bono statu Johannis Noreys, Armiger, qui istam Ec∣clesiam...... nova edificavit.
DIV2.P: In a North Window, Westward, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Orate pro bono statu Johannis....
DIV2.P: South East of this Place lyes BUCKLE∣BURY, a Seat of the late Sir Henry Winchescomb,(said to be descended from the wealthy Clothier of Newbury) whose Daughter, and Coheiress, was married to Henry St. John, late Viscount Boling∣broke, in whose Right he possesses this Estate.

DIV2.HEAD: STANFORD-DINGLEY,
DIV2.P: So called, to distinguish it from two other Places of the same Name, in the Hundred of Ganfield, and Reading, is a Rectory in the Hundred of Fair Cross, and Deanery of Newbury. Patron Mr. Sayer; Incumbent, the Reverend Mr. Sayer.

This Manor was in the Possession of Reginald Fitz-Herbert, who dying in 1285. by an Assignation, made it over to his Wife Joan. It afterwards was enjoyed by the noble, and antient Family of Clare, of whom Gilbert de Clare, Earl of Glou∣cester, slain at the Battle of Bannocks-Bourn, near Strivelin, (having first set∣tled it on his Wife Mud, in 1314.) in de∣fault of Male Issue, made his Three Sisters Co-heiresses. On 8 Feb. 1348. the Day of Hugh de Spencer's Death, we find it in his possession, from whom it descended to Elizabeth, his Wife, who dying 20 June, 1358. left it to her Husband's Brother's Son, Edward, who dying upon Martinmass Day, 1374. left it to his Wife, Elizabeth, who died in 1409. This came afterwards into the Hands of Richard Nevil▪ Earl of Warwick, and on his Demise, on Easter-Day,
1470. descended to his Wife, who was, in a manner, forced to settle it by an Act of Parliament on her Two Daugh∣ters, married to George Duke of Clarence, and Richard Duke of Gloucester. This Settlement held till 1487. but was then repealed, and by a special Feoffment dated 13 Dec. it was conveyed over to King Hen. VII. by the old Countess of Warwick.
in the North Ile lyes a Grave-stone, whereon is the Figure of a Woman in her usual Habit, with the following Epitaph.

Q.L: Sub jacet hoc lapide Mergret Dynley tumulata,
Quondam Willelmi Dynley conjux vocitata,
Armigeri Regis modo, vermibus esca parata.
M Dni. C quater, quater X quater I cadit illa
Romani festo Jesus ergo sui memor esto.

DIV2.P: At the Feet of the former lyes a little Stone, whereon is the Figure of a Man in a Gown, on Brass, and under his Feet this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of JOHN LYFORD, Citizen, and Merchant Taylour of London; who departed the 10th Day of Aprill, An°. 1610. aged 71 yeares, borne in this Parish of Stanford, who had 18 Children.

DIV2.HEAD: CHEVELY,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Hundred of Fair-Cross, and Deanery of Newbury. Patron Mr. Pocock; Incumbent, the Reverend Mr. Trigge. In this Parish is a Seat cal∣led Priour's Court.

Under the South Window of the Chan∣cel lies a Marble Grave-stone, with a Brass Plate on it, whereon is the Repre∣sentation of Mr..:.... Blanchard, of Priour's Court, In his Barrister's Gown, and under him these Verses.

Q.L: Loe, here he lyeth, whose Vertues rare, in Law, whose learned Skill,
A Mirrour was unto the good, a Terror to the ill.
If just Men's Soules doe live with God, if Wisdome merris Fame.
We, doubts but Heaven his Soule doth keepe, as Earth retaines his Name.

DIV2.HEAD: WELFORD,
DIV2.P: Is a Rectory in the Hundred of Fair-Cross, and Deanery of Newbury. Patron Mr. Sherly; Incumbent, the Reverend Mr. Sherly. In this Place is a Seat be∣longing to Mr. Archer.

Near to the East Window, against the North Wall of the Chancel, is erected a
fair Monument, where there is a Wo∣man in her usual Habit, kneeling at a Desk, and under her is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: ANNA GULIELMI REDE, Militis, fi∣lia ADRIANI FORTESCUE, & postea THOMAE PARRY, Militum, Uxor, hic sita est. Reliquit ex numerosa Proles superstites ex Fortescuo filios tres, fi∣lias duas. Ex Parrio duos filios & fili∣am unam, caeteris immaturè decedenti∣bus, ipsa vero, cum utriusque familioe fundamenta restaurasset, Aetatis suae Anno 75. Humanitatem exuit quin∣to Januarii, Anno Domini, MDLXXXV. R. Elizabetha Regnante.
DIV2.P: Engraven on the Foreside of this Monu∣ment, under the former, is this Inscription.

DIV2.HEAD: THOMAS FORTESCUE, f. Matri opti∣mae Posuit.
DIV2.P: In the middle of the Chancel, under the Figure of a Priest in his Vestments, having a shorn Crown, are these Verses, on a Brass Plate fixed to the Grave-stone.

Q.L: Quisquis eris, qui transiis, sta, perlege, plora,
Sum quod eris, fueramque quod pro me precor ora.
Re Christe Westlake anime miserere Johannis.

DIV2.P: Upon another Brass Plate, on a Grave-stone, on the South Side of the Chancel, is this Inscription
DIV2.Q: Of your Charite pray for the Soules of John Younge, John, Thomas, Elyn, and Susan, his Children, whose Soules Ihetu pardon.

DIV2.HEAD: WINTER BORNE Chapel,
DIV2.P: Is a Chapel of Ease to Chevely, in which Parish it lyes.
In 1329. I find a Charter of Free War∣ren, in this Lordship, granted to John Grey, Son of Robert, and Nephew of Wal∣ter Arch-Bishop of York.
On a Free-stone, in the Chancel, is this Inscriptiou.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of John Pococke, who departed the First of of October, 1657.
DIV2.P:
In the Belfry there lyes a thick Plank of Wood, formerly it seems to have been a Monument over a Grave, and on the
upper Part of it is imbossed a double Cross.
About a Mile from Newbury lyes

DIV2.HEAD: SHAW,
DIV2.P: In the Hundred of Fair-Cross, washed by the rapid Kennet, where is a handsome House, Garden, and Park, lately belong∣ing to Sir Thomas Doleman, Kt. and on his decease descended to his Nephew. Of the Family Doleman, I find one, Tho∣mas, was High-Sheriff this County in 1588. Sir George Lisle, murdered in Cold Blood, by that infamous Rebel, Fairfax, was at the second Newbury Battle in 16.... posted here. Over the Portico is a mangled Inscription, of which take the following Draught, though little can be concluded from it.

Q.P: MDLLXXI.
Here is a Fleur de Lis. . . I.
A little higher.
EDENTULUS VESCENTIN. DENTIBUS INVIDET. ET OCULOS CAPREARUM TAI. PA . C. CONTEMNIT.

DIV2.P: Within this Parish, in the high Road to Oxford, is a handsome Seat belonging to Thomas Cowslade, Es{que} Barrister at Law, of the Inner Temple, in London. Patron Mr. Doleman; Rector, the Reve∣rend Mr. Hinton.
North West of Newbury, adjoyning on this Parish, lyes

DIV2.HEAD: SPEEN,
DIV2.P: The antient Roman Spinae, a Town of great Antiquity, and no less Reputation. Through it runs the River Kennet. It is a Vicaridge in the Hundred of Fair-Cross, and Deanery Newbury. Patron the Bi∣shop of Saram; Incumbent, the Reverend Mr. Sandyland.

This Manor was in the possession of Hugh de Spencer, and at his Death came to his Wife, Aliva, Daughter of Philip Basset, of Wicombe in Bucking hamshire, who died in 1280. and left it to that noted Favourite, Hugh de Spencer, senior, her Son. In 1297. he had a Charter granted him by King Edw. 1. of Free Warren, in this Lordship, and in 1325. was murdered,
and his Estate forfeited. It was afterwards restored by King Ed. 3. to Hugh, a Son of the younger de Spencer, who died in quiet Possession (excepting an Annuity granted 1326. to Tho. de Brotherton, Earl of Norfolk) 8 Febr. 1348. leaving Edward, Son of his Brother Edward, his Heir. In 1397. Thomas of Woodstock, Earl of Buck∣ingham, and Duke of Gloucester, in right of Alianore, his Wife (one of the Daugh∣ters, and Heirs of Humfrey de Bohun, Earl of Hereford and Essex) was seized of two Parts of the Manor of Woodspene: These were afterwards granted to Edmund de Strafford, 1399. who died in 1402.

At the End of the South. Ile, called Castilion's Ile, stands a fair raised Monu∣ment of Free-stone, whereon lyes the Statue of a Man in Armour, having a Helmet lying under his Head, and his Feet resting upon his Crest, on the Ledge of the Tomb is this Epitaph circumscri∣bed.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Jo. Baptist Castilion, Ar∣miger, quondam Dominus de Benham, in comitatu Berks, qui Obiit 12 Febr. An. Domini, 1597.
DIV2.P: Over against the said Monument, in the Wall next the Chancel, stands ano∣ther raised Monument of Free Stone also, whereon lyes the Statue of a Woman in the Dress of her Time, and over all a large Veil, and this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Dominae Elizabethae Castilion, ex prae∣nobili & inclita familia de St. John de Blenesho, Uxori dulcissimae & desideratissimae, quae in puerperio, obiit 28. Dec 1603. Anno Aetatis 27. Franciscus Castillion, Miles, in perpetuum fidei & amoris Conjugalis Monumentum posuit, 1604.
DIV2.P: Near unto the North Wall of the Chan∣cel lyes a Grave-stone, bearing a Plate of Brass, with the Figure of a Priest in his Vestments, holding a Chalice and Pix be∣tween his Hands, out of his Mouth issues this Scrowl.

Q.L: Adhesit anima mea post te ne sus∣cepit dextra tua.
Ihesu Mercy, graunt Mercy.

DIV2.P: Under his Feet is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Of your Charite pray for the Soule of Sir John Foster, sume∣time Parson of Upway, and Vicar of this Church, who departed the Second Day of May, in the Yere of our Lord God, 1533. On whose Soule Ihesu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P:
In the Limits of this Parish, situate up∣on an Eminence, is DONNINGTON Castle, which is said to have been erect-by Sir Richard de Adderbury, to whom this Lordship belonged. When in its Glory it was a handsom, well fortified Place, and had underneath it an Hospital for several Poor. This, in process of Time, became the Seat of Sir Geoffry Chaucer, the Prince of English Poetry, who compo∣sed many of his celebrated Pieces under an Oak in this Park, of which more here∣after. His Son, Thomas Chaucer, Es{que} was High Sheriff of this County in 1400. whose Daughter, Alice, was married to William de la Pole, Duke of Suffolk, from whom it descended, and was by a Grant from King Hen. VIII. bestowed on Charles Brandon, Duke of Suffolk. In the unna∣tural
Rebellion, this Place was in the Possession of Mr. John Packer, and was garrisoned by King Charles I. under the Command of Sir John Boys, and was of great Use, that it commanded the great Roads from the West to London, and from Oxford to Newbury, It was once besieged by the Rebels under Colonel Horton, who raised a Battery against it at the Foot of a Hill near Newbury, by which he de∣molished Three of the Towers, and a part of the Wall.
